comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
During today's meeting, we asked how RA mode interacts with CRMF [RFC4211] style CSRs.

CRMF CSRs are a bit structurally different from PKCS#10 CSRs:

```
   CertReqMsg ::= SEQUENCE {
      certReq   CertRequest,
      popo       ProofOfPossession  OPTIONAL,
      -- content depends upon key type
      regInfo   SEQUENCE SIZE(1..MAX) of AttributeTypeAndValue OPTIONAL
   }

However, inclusion of additional
   certReq content by RAs can invalidate the popo field (depending on
   the details of the POP method used).  Therefore, data intended for
   certificate content MAY be provided in regInfo.
```

While with PKCS#10 it is common for the RA to consume the PoP signature and replace it with the RA's signature; in CRMF it is explicit that the signature is a PoP and anything the RA adds needs to go in the regInfo -- ie the RA is not allowed to modify the certReq.

At a quick glance, I don't see anything in RFC4211 describing how an RA would add a counter-signature, but presumably there exist CRMF extensions for this? Or maybe the intention is that the communication between RA and CA is "backend" and does not require explicit authentication / authorization / integrity protection at the CRMF layer? That would agree with `popo` being an optional field. Hendrik would know for sure.

I think, in the end, for this CSR Attest draft we can simply say nothing about this.

comments.author: HBrock
comments.body:
> While with PKCS#10 it is common for the RA to consume the PoP signature and replace it with the RA's signature; 

From how I understand PKCS#10, this statement is not correct. 
PKCS#10 always contains in the signature field of CertificationRequest a a signature of the certificationRequestInfo field as self-signature as PoP using the private key corresponding to the public key in subjectPKInfo, see Section 4.2 of [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2986](url).
The certificationRequestInfo field itself contains the subject, the subjectPKInfo and the attributes, see Section 4.1 of [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2986](url).
If the RA changes anything about the content of thee certificationRequestInfo field, the PoP is not valid anymore.

> in CRMF it is explicit that the signature is a PoP and anything the RA adds needs to go in the regInfo -- ie the RA is not allowed to modify the certReq.

Regarding CRMF the situation may be simpler, in case the RA uses the raVerified choice in the popo field of the CertReqMsg, see [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4211#section-4](url). This allows the CA to delegate the PoP validation to the RA. Specifically when the RA needs to change the content of the the certReq field the raVerified choice is handy.
In case the CA did not delegate the PoP validation to the RA, the RA could, depending on the certificate management protocol used, either put the original certReq containing the valid PoP into the regInfo field of the new certReqMsg (I guess this is how CMC is handling this case) or put the original  PKIMessage containing the valid PoP into the generalInfo field of the header of the new PKIMessage signed by the RA, see [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc4210bis-18#section-5.1.1.3](url).

> At a quick glance, I don't see anything in RFC4211 describing how an RA would add a counter-signature, but presumably there exist CRMF extensions for this? Or maybe the intention is that the communication between RA and CA is "backend" and does not require explicit authentication / authorization / integrity protection at the CRMF layer? That would agree with popo being an optional field. Hendrik would know for sure.

CRMF is a format and not a protocol. Therefore, it leaved this question to the certificate management protocol using CRMF.
In CMP we described this use case in [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9483#section-5.2.3](url) and [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9483#section-5.3.1](url).

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Hendrik Brockhaus ***@***.***> wrote:
    > If the RA changes anything about the content of thee
    > certificationRequestInfo field, the PoP is not valid anymore.

Yes, the RA is expected to have validated the PoP, and then indicate that to
the CA through the private relationship.
I don't think I'm disagreeing with you, and I argued not to label that arc
for this exact reason.

    > In case the CA did not delegate the PoP validation to the RA, the RA
    > could, depending on the certificate management protocol used, either
    > put the original certReq containing the valid PoP into the regInfo
    > field of the new certReqMsg (I guess this is how CMC is handling this
    > case) or put the original  PKIMessage containing the valid PoP into the
    > generalInfo field of the header of the new PKIMessage signed by the RA,
    > see
    > [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc4210bis-18#section-5.1.1.3](url).

CMC does this better than other choices.
Most systems just have a private relationship/API between RA and CA.
As was mentioned on Monday's call, at some point the RA was a human you
presented yourself to.

issues.title: Mike StJohns WGLC comments
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
1) The "hint" field and it's processing continues to be underspecified.  The body of the document actually refers to the non-normative examples in the appendix rather than giving a precise explanation of how to process the hint field.  The "hint" field, as defined, suggests that the verifier architecture being proposed is somewhat problematic in that there MUST be a separate process or server that's responsible for verifying the attestation, and that there may be multiple servers or processes that are responsible for verifying a specific attestation type (e.g. as identified by the "type" field in the evidence statement.)  How a CA should process a CSR for which an unknown hint is provided does not appear to be specified for example. Nor how to deal with multiple competing verifiers all claiming to be able to verify a given evidence type.  The document specifies how the hint is placed, but not how it should be processed.

2) EVIDENCE-STATEMENT is defined using the TYPE-IDENTIFIER construct, but the instantiation of this (EvidenceStatement) has an optional field - the aforementioned "hint".  As a general matter, a better definition would include an argument indicating whether or not the "hint" field should or should not be populated for a given definition of EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.  See below.

3) The "hint" field is defined as "IA5String" because the format of the field is an ASCII domain name and possibly a port number.  Unfortunately, that makes the field unusable for any other attestation type that may want to use the field for a meaning specific to its attestation type.  E.g. say an ASN1 structured field that gives additional - non-attester-signed information that may be used to map raw information in the attestation to something a PKIX system understands.

Notes:

The current definition of the EVIDENCE-STATEMENT and its instantiation is:


EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= TYPE-IDENTIFIER

EvidenceStatementSet EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= {
   ... -- None defined in this document --
}

EvidenceStatement ::= SEQUENCE {
   type   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&id({EvidenceStatementSet}),
   stmt   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&Type({EvidenceStatementSet}{@type}),
   hint   IA5String OPTIONAL
}


So defining a specific type of evidence statement would be "MikesStatement EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= MikesASN1Structure IDENTIFIED BY id-mikes-statement" where MikesASN1Structure would be defined elsewhere.

Considering (2) only, a better definition would be.  (Note that "TYPE-IDENTIFIER" is actually a well-known CLASS definition - there is no more complexity here in a CLASS definition than you would find using TYPE-IDENTIFIER)

EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= CLASS {
  &id              OBJECT IDENTIFIER UNIQUE,
  &Type,
  &hintPresent     ParamOptions DEFAULT required,
} WITH SYNTAX {
  &Type IDENTIFIED BY &id
  [HINT IS &ancillaryPresent]
}

Allowing for "MikesStatement EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= MikesASN1Structure IDENTIFIED BY id-mikes-statement HINT IS absent".  And allowing the relying party to know whether or not the absence of a hint is an error.


But considering (2) and (3) - the more correct definition would be:

EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= CLASS {
  &id           OBJECT IDENTIFIER UNIQUE,
  &Type,
  &ancillaryPresent       ParamOptions DEFAULT absent,
  &AncillaryType   DEFAULT OCTET STRING
} WITH SYNTAX {
  &Type IDENTIFIED BY &id
  [ANCILLARY [TYPE &AncillaryType] IS &ancillaryPresent]

}

EvidenceStatementSet EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= {
   ... -- None defined in this document --
}

EvidenceStatements ::= SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF EvidenceStatement

EvidenceStatement ::= SEQUENCE {
   type   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&id({EvidenceStatementSet}),
   stmt   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&Type({EvidenceStatementSet}{@type}),
   ancillary   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&AncillaryType({EvidenceStatementSet}{@ancillaryType}) OPTIONAL
}


Allowing for "MikesStatement EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= MikesASN1Structure IDENTIFIED BY id-mikes-statement ANCILLARY TYPE MikesAncillary IS required"

If I want to allow the authors to not have to change their "EVIDENCE-STATEMENT" definitions, I would change ancillaryPresent to "DEFAULT preferredPresent"  ("required"?) and ancillary type to "DEFAULT IA5String".

This doesn't fix the overall problem with the "hint" field nor with the general "requires an external verifier" architecture implied by the way this is written, but does allow for important flexibility that's missing in the current definition.

_______________________________  END Shepherd text


Nit:  If the "hint" field is restricted to a set of characters or even a pattern, then a Hint type should be defined consisting of "IA5String (CONTAINING ...)".  E.g. the ASN1 equivalent of BNF for the field.  This field is well-defined structure wise in the text, so the ASN1 should reflect that definition to allow for automated checking for processing units compiled from this ASN1.

Nit: EvidenceStatementSet - multiple places - has "... -- None defined in this document --" in its body.  Given that there appear to be at least two EVIDENCE-STATEMENT definitions in the body of this draft (both using real OIDs rather than example OIDs), perhaps this is incorrect?

Nit: The section 7.3.2 references for original registry contents are bogus as to all of the TCG/TPM references.   The references here should be to where specific EVIDENCE-STATEMENTs are defined, not to where the OIDs are mentioned.  If there are no defined EVIDENCE-STATEMENTS for a given OID, then delete the registration.

Nit: The section 7.3 IANA considerations for the registry definition should use the language from 5226 and should use one of the specific terms - e.g. "Document Required" or "Standard Required" etc.

Nit: Section7.3.2 again - "Change Controller".  This is a somewhat weird nomenclature.  I would note somewhere that this is actually the document controller, and that updates of the reference will only be accepted for changes to the definition which meet general ASN1 extensibility rules.  E.g. if there are no "..." in the structure definition, then there are no updates possible...  Perhaps instead there is a column indicating whether the base definition is meant to be extensible?

Note that the definition I gave above for EVIDENCE-STATEMENT was mostly the same as my original definition of the ATTESTATION-STATEMENT in the pre-adoption draft, so this should not be a surprise to the authors.

Later, Mike

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Proposed responses:


1, 2, 3:
You've raised these objections already multiple times. The authors have discussed it multiple times, and we are happy with the current specification. It's insane to me how much this this draft has been delayed over a completely OPTIONAL part that is on purpose an under-specified hint.  If you don't want to use the hint in your application, fine. Maybe it will turn out to be useless and nobody uses it, also fine. 

Sentences like this tell me that you fundamentally don't understand what we're trying do to with the hint:

"Allowing for "MikesStatement EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= MikesASN1Structure IDENTIFIED BY id-mikes-statement HINT IS absent". And allowing the relying party to know whether or not the absence of a hint is an error."

If your ASN.1 / OID already uniquely defines whether or not a hint should be present, then you probably don't need the hint because it's likely already fully-specified enough. The hint is a place for a proprietary Attester to communicate to the RP that this data would be easiest to parse with a given proprietary verifier instead of whatever default thing the RP would otherwise try. I can't imagine a case where absence of a hint would be an error; that just means that the RP doesn't get a hint to help with format-sniffing. The hint is intended to be completely non-normative in every possible way.


We're done spending time debating the hint. Done now.




You say:

"Nit: EvidenceStatementSet - multiple places - has "... -- None defined in this document --" in its body. Given that there appear to be at least two EVIDENCE-STATEMENT definitions in the body of this draft (both using real OIDs rather than example OIDs), perhaps this is incorrect?"

Can you please point to where you see that in the body? I see Appendix A.1. Extending EvidenceStatementSet, but I do not consider that to be in the body or normative enough to be worth including in the core ASN.1 definition.



You say:

"Nit: The section 7.3.2 references for original registry contents are bogus as to all of the TCG/TPM references. The references here should be to where specific EVIDENCE-STATEMENTs are defined, not to where the OIDs are mentioned. If there are no defined EVIDENCE-STATEMENTS for a given OID, then delete the registration."

Respectfully disagree. This is a registry of "OIDs you might see in the wild". Whether or not a specification exists which does the trivial thing of defining an EVIDENCE-STATEMENTS for it is rather irrelevant.

Also, I take this comment to be non-constructive filibustering: EVIDENCE-STATEMENTS is defined in this document, which is not yet published, so how could there be any 3rd party specifications that use it? I take this comment to be a complicatedly-worded attempt to have us delete this section, and I don't appreciate it.



You say:

"Nit: The section 7.3 IANA considerations for the registry definition should use the language from 5226 and should use one of the specific terms - e.g. "Document Required" or "Standard Required" etc."

Umm. "Document Required" is not defined in [RFC5226]. However "Designated Expert" is, so I believe that the current wording of this section already satisfies your comment. That said, on re-reading [RFC5226], "Specification Required" does more accurately cover the intention here, so I will change "Designated Expert" to "Specification Required". Thanks.

 "Document controller" vs "Change controller": I see where you're coming from, but since we want to allow for proprietary data formats to be listed here, I think

comments.author: mstjohns
comments.body:
I think you need to remove the AttestationResults text and ASN1.  Basically, it's fine to sort of let the attester to verifier be many different types (e.g. TPM, conceptual wrappers, etc) and depend on a third party to provide Verifiers, but you can't really do that with the Verifier to CA/RA link.

An attestation result IMHO needs to be a concrete, standard result with perhaps a few different optional components.  It needs to be signed by a verifier, and it should be understandable by the CA/RA.  E.g. it needs to be PKIX from top to bottom with no opaque fields. 

As a minimum, the AttestationResult is going to need to look something like:

SignedAttestationResult ::= SIGNED {AttestationResult}

AttestationResult ::= SEQUENCE {
      keyLink CHOICE {  -- The attestation must be cryptographicly associated with the key being bound to a certiicate
            keyId SEQUENCE {    
                  hashType OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
                  hash OCTET STRING },
            key  SubjectPublicKeyInfo }
      keyInfo  KeyAttrs,
      entityInfo EntityAttrs,
      verifierInfo VerifierAttrs }

The first part of this is just linking the attestation result to the key being certified.  The CA/RA needs to verify what the Verifier is talking about in a secure manner.  

The next part is the translation of the various EvidenceStatements into something the CA/RA can use to determine whether or not to issue a certificate.

KeyAttrs is probably a BIT STRING representing standard key attributes (e.g. generated in hardware, not extractable, etc), followed by an optional SEQUENCE of CHOICE of either OID or SingleAttribute.  That second part is mostly extensions of the first part and provides for non BOOLEAN attributes if necessary.  It's possible this just reduces to a sequence of OID that represents the policies the key meets.

EntityAttrs is probably similar to KeyAttrs - but describes the entity containing the key/attesting the key.  Things like hardware version, device type, firmware version/date.  

I think that ALL of that is way past the scope of this document and, if kept, won't be able to progress.   It's currently a kitchen sink sitting on a couple of saw horses with neither the water hooked up to the faucets nor the drain hooked to the drain hole.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
> I can't see how AR could be inserted by the Verifier into the CSR. If the verifier (operated by the HSM manufacturer, or their representative) needs to communicate things other than pass/fail with the RP (the CA), then they need a different protocol.

I expect we'll see a lot of "Pass/Fail for a given evidence verification profile" (or whatever the right RATS term is for that). Like "Does this CSR indicate compliance with CA/B BRs?", or "Did this CSR come from TPM-backed CAPI on a fully-patched Windows?". Or maybe even, the CA hands the verifier a list of evidence verification profiles (maybe each with its own trust store), and the Verifier hands back a list of profiles that this CSR complies with, the CA then smacks the corresponding OIDs on the cert.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> I expect we'll see a lot of "Pass/Fail for a given evidence verification profile" (or whatever the right RATS term is for that). Like "Does this CSR indicate compliance with CA/B BRs?", or "Did this CSR come from TPM-backed CAPI on a fully-patched Windows?". Or maybe even, the CA hands the verifier a list of evidence verification profiles (maybe each with its own trust store), and the Verifier hands back a list of profiles that this CSR complies with, the CA then smacks the corresponding OIDs on the cert.

Sure, but none of those messages can go INTO the CSR. Because it's signed by the Attester, and the Verifier can't modify that.
RATS does not define a protocol between RP and Verifier: we have to pick one or design one.
Your initial proposal that it's a proprietary popen("|hsm-manufacturer-module") is probably a good one for now.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Where does the terminology conflict with  RFC 9334 and RFC 4949 terminology?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
A few prominent examples:

* Examples of major conflicts
    * w.r.t. RFC 9334, `This evidence is to be verified by a relying party`: "verified" means nothing in the RATS scope and Evidence is never appraised by a Relying Party - only by Verifiers
    * w.r.t. RFC 4949, `certificate chains` is a term deprecated at least for 15 years and `certification path` should be used.
* Examples of minor conflicts
    * `evidence signed by certificate chains` This makes no sense. An Attester signes Evidence and it probably should sign with appropriate key material that is endorsed via certification paths
    * to stay in sync with RFC 9334 (colloquial) language, it is preferable to write that RATS conceptual messages are `conveyed` and not `carried`

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body:
I created two PRs to address the issues you have raised above instead of re-writing the text altogether. 

Three comments:

* Certificate chains is not a depreciated term. It depends what you want to say. 
* The terms "convey" and "carry" (or "transport") mean the same thing.
* The term "appraise" is something that aims to give the impression that there is something magic going on while in reality you are just comparing the provided data against some reference values. "Verification" is more natural.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Comments:

1.
In the aasvg, you have "1..n EvidenceBundle", "0..n CertificateAlternatives", and "1..n EvidenceStatement".
I agree that's how I also imagine this being user,d but technically they are all declared as SEQUENCE, so are all 0..n. 
For example, if your Evidence is already an X.509 certificate then you could conceivably put that in the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives and leave the SEQUENCE OF EvidenceStatement empty. I'm not sure that's a good idea, but it is allowed under the current definitions.


2.
I think we should add a usecase that deals with Endorsements. This is related to #63. 
Possibly just modify the wording of #3 to "... multiple Attesters or Endorsers", and "... Evidence or Endorsement statements".


3.
I think there are actually two valid ways of addressing #4: the one you describe where a Verifier has to look across EvidenceBundles in order to find the complete cert chains that it needs, or merging all of those into a single EvidenceBundle with a single de-duplicated SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives; that would look like:

```
 +-------------------------+
 |  EvidenceBundle         |
 +-------------------------+
 | EvidenceStatements {     |
 |   EvidenceStatement (1)  |
 |   ...                     |
 |  EvidenceStatement (n)  |
 | }                         |
 | CertificateAlternatives { |
 |  EndEntity (1)          |
 |  ...                     |
 |  EndEntity (n)            |
 | <remainder of           |
 |     certificate chain >     |
 | }                   |
 +-------------------------+
```

We could call what you wrote 4a, and this 4b. 4a helps the verifier by providing 1-to-1 mapping between EvidenceStatements and the EndEntity certificate to verify it, but makes the Relying Party implementation more complicated, for example by needing to re-assemble complete certificate chains across EvidenceBundles if the Verifier needs to be invoked separately for each EvidenceStatement.
Whereas 4b means that each EvidenceBundle is self-contained and any EvidenceStatement can be verified using only the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives in its bundle, but Verifiers will have to do proper certificate path building since the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives is now a cert bag and not a cert chain.
Pros and Cons to both.

```suggestion
~~~ aasvg
```

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: I don't have push permissions on Monty's fork, so I am merging into a side branch, I'll do a few fixes, then merge into main.

Hello! 👋🏻 Great write-up! I was reading through and got a bit confused by this line, specifically by `the EK is used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key`. My understanding was that the EK is used to assure a 3rd party (in this case the Privacy CA / Attestation CA) that the AK is in the same TPM as the EK, not for the CA to issue the AK. Am I getting this wrong?

I think we are saying the same thing. The Attestation CA is just a special CA that uses the TPM protocols (including the EK) to prove the AK is in the same TPM (and has the expected attributes). The Attestation CA then issues a certificate for the AK. Since the AK is a signing key (the EK is a decryption key so the protocol is a bit awkward and non-standard - again, this is one of the reasons we use the term Attestation CA because it acts as a non-standard CA) it is easier to get a signed statement about the properties of a "user key". Defining that signed statement is the point of this effort.
Agree, but I don't see how that maps to `used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key` - perhaps `used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key certificate` is clearer?

Ha, you are correct. Authors sometimes miss the subtitle wording and when I read ...create and Attestation Key... I meant what you said. A subtle but very important difference. Thanks for pointing this out.

pulls.title: Addressing Carl's review
pulls.author: ounsworth
pulls.body:
Closes #126 

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/UVQ0yXAEqsm9snJIOcelFQoYyEA/


Responses to Carl:
---

> "Residency" doesn't seem quite right since it misses the non-exportability requirement that is usually a goal. Maybe steal some verbiage from the CAB Forum guidelines and say: "Regulatory bodies are beginning to require proof that keys are generated in a non‐exportable way using a suitable Hardware Crypto Module."

I am going to leave this one as-is. I think that "proof of hardware residency" is not incorrect, and is made more precise in the following sentence, including the direct quote from the CA/B CSBRs.



> The last paragraph leaves open the possibility of having multiple instantiations of attr-evidence or ext-evidence but does not mention the fact that the values field in Attribute can contain multiple values. Do we really need three ways to convey multiple evidence bundles, i.e., via EvidenceBundles, via multiple attributes, via multiple attribute values? Is there any reason to not just limit this to one attribute/extension, one value within attribute and let EvidenceBundles handle collections?


Yes, good point.
I have attempted to strengthen this, but I would love review of the new paragraph. Have I correctly understood and referenced the AttributeSet and ExtensionSet stuff from RFC5912? Is there a better way to enforce this through the ASN.1 definitions?

> Section 5.3 CertificateAlternatives

Given the on-list discussion, and that we have subsequently fully removed the CertificateAlternatives section, I am going to mostly skip over this feedback as no longer relevant.

> Section 5.3
> - Given the use of Verifier throughout, if enforcement of RFC5280 compliance is to be addressed by this spec, perhaps it should be allocated to the verifier instead of the relying party.

I don't understand this comment at all? What are we enforcing for 5280 compliance? The CSR? -- I am imagining that the Verifier won't get to see the full CSR, just the evidence blob that has been forklifted out of it.

> Section 7.1
> - Either add a reference to draft-birkholz-rats-epoch-markers in support of` "Epochs also require" or delete that sentence. The section is fine without the reference to Epochs.

So, this sentence is going through RATS Architecture [RFC9334} sections 10.1, 10.2, and 10.3, and saying why each is not a general solution here. I generified the sentence a bit so that it fits better within the scope of RFC9334 10.3.

> Section 7.2
> - The NOT RECOMMENDED here is inconsistent with the MUST NOT in section 5.2. NOT RECOMMENDED seems right.
> - Given the words throughout about not using the extension type in a certificate, ought there be some words about not using the attribute type in a subject directory attributes extension in a certificate?

These are excellent points. I have opened a separate pull request (#138) so that they can be discussed separately.

> Section 7.3
> - How does the last sentence of this section apply to this draft, i.e., where could one express "None, Null, Debug, empty CMW contents, or similar values"?

I see your point, but I think I'm going to leave it; I think it reads ok. Could you please read it again and see if you still feel strongly about that sentence?

> Section B.1
> - This should probably be presented as a standalone ASN.1 module that adds this definition instead of as a snip from an ASN.1 module.

I will discuss with @nedmsmith .

Per [RFC6125](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6125#section-2.2), if we support Unicode, we support internationalized FQDNs and all the UTF8 and punycode support right? I know that is not part of the scope of this I-D, but worth calling out.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
We ended up looking at FQDNs because the review feedback was concerned about possible misuse. But if the I-D specifies expected use, then it seems the intended usage is that of an identifier (and nothing more). Hence, it is useful as a key for searching a list but not as an address that could invoke network services that might exist outside of an administrative domain or require network connectivity (assuming the list is local). The I-D didn’t want to specify the type of identifier, just let the application developer choose.

Hence, something generic like byte string or text string seems good enough.

Cheers,
Ned

From: A.J. Stein ***@***.***>
Date: Tuesday, July 2, 2024 at 07:27
To: lamps-wg/csr-attestation ***@***.***>
Cc: Smith, Ned ***@***.***>, Comment ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [lamps-wg/csr-attestation] New Hint Text Proposal (PR #143)

@aj-stein-nist commented on this pull request.

________________________________

In draft-ietf-lamps-csr-attestation.md<https://github.com/lamps-wg/csr-attestation/pull/143#discussion_r1662520148>:

> +In some cases, the EvidenceStatement.type OID will be sufficient information

+for the Relying Party to correctly route it to an appropriate Verifier,

+however since the type OID only identifies the general data format, it is possible

+that multiple Verifiers are registered against the same type OID in which case the

+Relying Party will either require additional parsing of the evidence statement, or

+the Attester will be required to provide additional information.

+

+To simplify the task for the Relying Party an optional field, the hint, is available

+in the EvidenceStatement structure, as shown in {{code-EvidenceStatement}}. An

+Attester MAY include the hint to the EvidenceStatement and it MAY be processed

+by the Relying Party. The Relying Party MAY decide not to trust the information

+embedded in the hint or policy MAY override any information provided by the Attester

+via this hint.

+

+When the Attester populates the hint, it MUST contain a fully qualified domain

+name (FQDN) which uniquely identifies a Verifier.

Nit - RFC6125 was obsoleted by RFC9525. It seems odd to reference this RFC (on TLS service identity) for a value that is not intended to be de-referenced.

I do not disagree, I could not really find the right reference to explain what FQDN is or is not without other necessary context, but I thought per the title, "Representation and Verification of Domain-Based Application Service
Identity within Internet Public Key Infrastructure Using X.509," aside from the TLS identity context. Are you suggesting a reference to RFC1034 is more suitable? Ironically 1034 does not reference the term FQDN, it seems to evolved from fully qualified address, total, or absolute domain. FQDN is not defined, so I thought it would be counterproductive.

If RFC1034 is not helpful, is there another you would recommend?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Just as a reminder, the _current_ text (-09 datatracker) is:

```
EvidenceStatement ::= SEQUENCE {
   type   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&id({EvidenceStatementSet}),
   stmt   EVIDENCE-STATEMENT.&Type({EvidenceStatementSet}{@type}),
   hint   UTF8String OPTIONAL
}
```

> The hint SHOULD contain a value which is unique to this Verifier, such as a fully qualified domain name (FQDN), a uniform resource name (URN) [[RFC8141](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8141)] or a registered value corresponding to this evidence format. It is assumed that the RP must be pre-configured with a list of trusted Verifiers and that the contents of this hint can be used to look up the correct Verifier. Under no circumstances must the RP be tricked into contacting an unknown and untrusted Verifier since the returned Attestation Result must not be relied on.

Ned's comment above seems to be coming full circle to the original (current) text.

The review feedback was that this is too loose, and instead of "UTF8String _such as_", we should make it more precise: "UTF8String which MUST be {something}", but we can't agree on what that {something} should be. A valid outcome is to put back the original text. I personally think it is already clear enough.

name (FQDN, per {{RFC6125}}) which uniquely identifies a Verifier.

It seems RFC1035 is too high-level and only refers to the traditional terms so may not be so helpful. If you do that and cite it here, it is something I would want to look up to know what "exactly you mean by FQDN" like I did during this review.

I know this suggestion is only partial, as I cannot suggest a reference for the citation, normative or informative, later in the document because you cannot make a suggestion in a chunk without a change or diff.

This sentence needs to be strengthened to say that the FQDN is simply an identifier. It MUST NOT be dereferenced, looked up in DNS, or FETCHED.

Question: is "FQDN" misleading here? Would calling it a URI make it less dangerous (or more dangerous??).

> Question: is "FQDN" misleading here? Would calling it a URI make it less dangerous (or more dangerous??).

Per this topic of discussion in an editors' meeting, this is specifically why I mentioned URN is preferable to URI. There is a reason I believed that was picked in the version modified by this PR.

 Identity within Internet Public Key Infrastructure Using X.509 ...," aside from the TLS identity context. Are you suggesting a reference to RFC1034 is more suitable? pulls.title: First version with passport model added.
pulls.author: hannestschofenig
pulls.body:
In this PR, I have added the long-awaited support for the passport model to the CSR attestation draft. While the functionality was implicitly present through the use of the conceptual message wrapper, the text previously lacked any explicit explanation.

I understand that introducing this functionality at this stage may seem late. However, I strongly believe we should not publish the draft without it, as there is significant industry interest in supporting both models: the background-check model and the passport model.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body:
Two points in response, Mike:

1. ASN.1 correctness: I’m not entirely sure about the validity of the included ASN.1. It seems we had a bug, which I noticed when extending it with this PR. We should review the ASN.1 carefully during an upcoming call.

2. Attestation Results certificate chains: Because the standardization efforts for Attestation Results (ARs) are relatively recent, I assumed the AR structure can carry these chains. However, it’s worth verifying this assumption.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Evidence are appraised by Verifiers, which generate Attestation Results that serve as input for validating incoming certificate requests against specified certificate policies. Verifiers are associated with Registration Authorities (RAs) or CAs and function as logical entities responsible for processing Evidence and producing Attestation Results. As remote attestation technology matures, it is natural for a Certificate Authority to want attested proof that the requesting entity is in a state that matches the certificate profile. At the time of writing, the most notable example is the Code-Signing Baseline Requirements (CSBR) document maintained by the CA/Browser Forum {{CSBR}}, which requires compliant CAs to "ensure that a Subscriber’s Private Key is generated, stored,
```

and used in a secure environment that has controls to prevent theft or misuse", which is a natural fit to enforce via remote attestation.
```

reviews.author: nedmsmith
reviews.body: See several comments.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Evidence are appraised by Verifiers, which typically produces Attestation Results that serve as input for validating incoming certificate requests against specified certificate policies.
Verifiers are associated with Registration Authorities (RAs) or CAs and function as logical entities responsible for processing Evidence and producing Attestation Results.
As remote attestation technology matures, it is natural for a Certification Authority to want proof that the requesting entity is in a state that matches the certificate profile.
At the time of writing, the most notable example is the Code-Signing Baseline Requirements (CSBR) document maintained by the CA/Browser Forum {{CSBR}}, which requires compliant CAs to "ensure that a Subscriber’s Private Key is generated, stored,
```

```suggestion
This specification defines an attribute and an extension that allow for conveyance of Evidence and Attestation Results in Certificate Signing Requests (CSRs), such as PKCS#10 {{RFC2986}} or Certificate Request Message Format (CRMF) {{RFC4211}} payloads.
This CSR extension satisfies CA/B Forum's CSBR {{CSBR}} requirements for key protection assurance.
```

```suggestion
As outlined in the IETF RATS architecture {{RFC9334}}, an Attester (typically a device) produces a signed collection of Claims that constitute Evidence about its running environment(s).
The term "attestation" is not explicitly defined in RFC 9334 but was later clarified in {{?I-D.ietf-rats-tpm-based-network-device-attest}}.
It refers to the process of generating and evaluating remote attestation Evidence.
```

NIST also defines it in SP1800-19 "The process of providing a digital signature for a set of measurements securely stored in hardware, and then having the requester validate the signature and the set of measurements."

```suggestion
After the Verifier appraises the Evidence, it generates a new structure called an Attestation Result.
A Relying Party utilizes Attestation Results to inform risk or policy-based decisions that consider trustworthiness of the attested entity.
This document relies on {{architecture}} as the foundation for how the various roles within the RATS architecture correspond to a certificate requester and a CA/RA.
```

```suggestion
The IETF RATS architecture {{RFC9334}} defines two communication patterns: the __background-check model_ and the _passport model_.
In the background-check model, the Relying Party receives Evidence in the CSR from the Attester and must interact with a Verifier service directly to obtain Attestation Results.
In contrast, the passport model requires the Attester to first interact with the Verifier service to obtain an Attestation Result token that is then relayed to the Relying Party.
This specification defines both communication patterns.
```

```suggestion
Several standard and proprietary remote attestation technologies are in use at the time of this writing.
This specification is technology-agnostic with respect to the various remote attestation technologies.
It is agnostic to Evidence and Attestation Results formats in two ways: (1) the CSR conveyance envelope regards Evidence and Attestation Results as an opaque payload and (2) the conveyance of sets of certificates, that may be used for validation of Evidence and Attestation Results, are also opaque payloads.
```

```suggestion
The certificates typically contain one or more certification paths rooted to a device manufacturer's trust anchor. End-entity certificates are in the certification path that contains a device ID certificate for the Attester device.
End-entity and alias (intermediary device) certificates are associated with key material that takes on the Attester role (a.k.a., Attestation Key) and are used to sign Evidence originating from the Attester.
```

```suggestion
Evidence are appraised by Verifiers, which generate Attestation Results that serve as input for validating incoming certificate requests against specified certificate policies. Verifiers are associated with Registration Authorities (RAs) or CAs and function as logical entities responsible for processing Evidence and producing Attestation Results.
As remote attestation technology matures, it is natural for a Certification Authority to want attested proof that the requesting entity is in a state that matches the certificate profile.
At the time of writing, the most notable example is the Code-Signing Baseline Requirements (CSBR) document maintained by the CA/Browser Forum {{CSBR}}, which requires compliant CAs to "ensure that a Subscriber’s Private Key is generated, stored,
```

```suggestion
- Evidence is placed into an EvidenceStatement structure along with an OID to identify its type and optionally a hint to the Relying Party about which Verifier (software package, a microservice or some other service) will be capable of parsing it.
A set of EvidenceStatement structures, along with a set of CertificateChoice structures, are grouped to form the EvidenceBundle structure.
The CertificateChoice structures are used to validate EvidenceStatement structures.
```

```suggestion
- Attestation Results are carried in the AttestationResult structure along with an OID to identify its type. A set of AttestationResult structures are grouped to form the AttestationResultBundle structure.
```
Are the CertificateChoice structures from above used to validate AttestationResult structures?

```suggestion
A CSR may contain one or more EvidenceBundle payloads.
For example Evidence
```

```suggestion
algorithms.
Like-wise a CSR may also contain one or more AttestationResultBundle payloads.
```

```suggestion
limited to the conveyance of Evidence and Attestation Results within a CSR.
The exact format of the Evidence and Attestation Results being conveyed is opaque to this
```

```suggestion
specification.
```

```suggestion
between the Attester and the Verifier is not feasible.
Or when Attestation Results are specific to a particular Relying Party.
```

```suggestion
Result token, which is subsequently included in the CSR.
```

I'm suggesting adding 'token' to Attestation Results when in the passport model, so that it is more clear that the Attester can't modify the Attestation Results before forwarding to Relying Parties.

Since the AR payload is opaque to this specification, it doesn't need to describe in detail a token fomat. However, the security assumptions should be clear.

```suggestion
As a result, one EvidenceBundle is included in a CSR that contains a single EvidenceStatement
```
Why? There could be multiple roots of trust each having disparate evidence and certification paths.

```suggestion
one or more AttestationResult structures.
```

More explanation is needed to describe cases where the AR payload may contain multiple tokens (can multiple Verifiers issue different AR tokens for the same Attester that a single CA should process?).  Are there other use cases motivating multiple ARs?

```suggestion
Evidence statement. Additional certificates may be provided for path construction, for example, to chain the
```

```suggestion
Evidence signer key back to an agreed upon trust anchor. No specific order of the certificates in `certs` SHOULD be expected because certificates contained in `certs` may be needed to validate different Evidence statements.
```

What about validating Attestation Results too?

I think its confusing for a crypto lib to have getEvidence calls. This dissonance is easier to see if you also have a diagram for getAttestationResultToken(). Both the AR token and Evidence are already signed (by Verifier / Attesting Env respectively) so there isn't a crypto operation needed to fetch them.

```suggestion
- Per-Use Attestation Keys: Devices may be designed to dynamically generate distinct attestation keys (and request the corresponding certificates) for each use case, device, or session. This is analogous to the Privacy CA model, in which a device is initially provisioned with an attestation key and certificate; then, in conjunction with a privacy-preserving CA, it can obtain unique keys and certificates as needed. This strategy reduces the potential for tracking while maintaining strong security assurances. This is the model described in this document.
```

Differential privacy analysis may be applied to Evidence, Attestation Results, or Certificates to reveal personally identifiable information that may be used to track a user or to correlate user's transactions.
I don't think certification requests are limited to end entities. SPDM and DICE device ID certs can be embedded CAs.
Good to know but the authors of the NIST document are incorrect in saying that this is securely stored in hardware.
There is a lot that could be done but I did not want to provide an exhaustive list
Fair enough. I will change this text.

comments.author: gmandyam
comments.body:
> Thanks for the contribution, Giri. The text is good but I am wondering why you only included the Platform Evidence token instead of also the Realm token. Could you explain?

I had not created a sample realm claim set yet, and this issue was pending for a while so I wanted to get something in for review.  I can add a realm token example.

One more question:  will a single OID be allocated for CCA token?  Or can different OID's be assigned for the different CCA attestation options?  I think t least for CSR's there could potentially be three:  (a) Platform token only, (b) DIrect model:  Platform token + realm claims set, where a hash of the realm claims set is included in the platform token payload as challenge data, and (c) Delegated model:  Platform token + Realm Attestation Token, where Platform token includes the Realm Attestation PubKey as challenge data.  Another option is to just assign one OID for CCA, and have the variants be identified by CBOR tags.

```suggestion
This specification defines an attribute and an extension that allow for conveyance of Evidence, Endorsements and Attestation Results in Certificate Signing Requests (CSRs), such as PKCS#10 {{RFC2986}} or Certificate Request Message Format (CRMF) {{RFC4211}} payloads.
```

```suggestion
Alternatively, the Attester might have a direct connection to a Verifier to which it presents its Evidence and Endorsements, and receives back an Attestation Result signed by the Verifier which it can include directly in the CSR and save the RA / CA from needing a local Verifier. This is referred to as the RATS Passport Model, and is illustrated in {{fig-arch-passport}}.
```

Regarding the explaination of the endorsement we could just refer to the definition in the RATS architecture draft, which says:

"
A secure statement that an Endorser vouches for the
integrity of an Attester's various capabilities, such as Claims
collection and Evidence signing.
"

I am also wondering whether we should mention the incorrect use of terminology by some companies. I have not seen anyone referring to the Attestation Key as an Endorsement. The RATS architecture RFC is, however, unclear on the use of the CA certificate that is the root of the chain of the AK certificate. Figure 1 in RFC 9334, for example, does not mention these Trust Anchors, which obviously need to be provisioned to the Verifier to have a working solution.

I believe this should rather say

AttestationResultBundle ::= SEQUENCE ....

Change the results-definition from AttestationResult to something else.
